results.title: Problems of conservation
results.brief_description: Highlights problems in the United States associated with the depletion of non-renewable natural resources; forest, mineral, wildlife and the associated problem of increasing air pollution. Discusses intervention strategies.

results.title: Solar water heating
results.creator_credit: Roger Morse, Ted Davey, S.T. Evans and CSIRO
results.brief_description: Collecting solar energy for use in water heaters. A CSIRO scientist explains how the absorbers work and, with the aid of diagrams, how they operate on the principle of thermo-cyclic-flow. Their installation and economy are also demonstrated.

results.title: Soil
results.creator_credit: John Walker and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Environment in crisis: problems of conservation”.
Shows what soil is and how it is formed - then illustrates the damaging effects of water and wind erosion. Another damaging depletion is the loss of nutrients in the soil. Illustrates with on the spot examples of how the U.S. conservation service in 1969 combated these projects that range from contour ploughing to land use planning.

results.title: Wildlife
results.creator_credit: John Walker and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Environment in crisis: problems of conservation”.
Explains the need for conservation of wildlife in order to preserve the ecological balance of nature. Describes the endangered status of many species today, what has been done to control impending extinction in the past, and what can be done in the future through refuges. In collaboration with Allan A. Sollers, author of “Ours is the Earth”.

results.title: Snatch [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Guy Ritchie, Matthew Vaughn and Columbia Pictures
results.brief_description: Guy Ritchie’s second feature follows on seamlessly from his first: the music video/caper movie, “Lock, Stock and Two Smoking Barrels”. It’s cast - peppered with Hollywood stars Benicio Del Toro, Dennis Farina and Brad Pitt - portray a crowd of London small-timers torturing, mutilating and wise-cracking their way across Ritchie’s home territory: ludicrous plots, racial stereotypes and groovy pop music, all in the name of derisively good fun. If “Lock, Stock” was an escapade into guilt-free sick violence, then “Snatch” is exactly the same.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Guy Ritchie, Matthew Vaughn and Columbia Pictures

results.title: Social psychology (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: James B. Lipscomb, Joel Gold, Carole Hart and CRM Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Psychology Today”.
Discusses psychological concepts applicable to the social problems arising from the school bussing of black children to previously all white schools. Interesting juxtaposition between the integrated classroom, and interviews with those who are opposed to bussing black children to all white schools. Emphasises the skill of the classroom teacher in being aware of preserving a positive self-image among the black children.
results.creator_credit_for_label: James B. Lipscomb, Joel Gold, Carole Hart and CRM Productions

results.title: The Sensory world (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Joel Gold, Philip Mendlow, Tom Lazarus and CRM Educational Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Psychology Today”
Examines and demonstrates the empirical mechanics of human perception or misperception of our environments and the functioning - both normal and impaired - of the human senses. Uses animation to demonstrate various phenomena of the brain and illustrates its functions. Includes explanation of experiments with optic fibres and with electrical stimulation of the human brain and the memory.
Suitable for upper secondary and teacher/tertiary levels.

results.title: Token economy: behavourism applied (TEFC)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Psychology Today”.
Elisabeth Hall, editor of Psychology Today, interviews the eminent Behaviourist, B.F. Skinner. Skinner explains, with examples, his theory of behaviour modification (“operant conditioning”) through positive and negative reinforcement. He cites the five classic examples of mistreatment, then explains the use of tokens in a program of reinforcement therapy. The director of the Adolf Meyer Centre explains how token economy is practised. Views all aspects of the Centre’s life and contrasts its extremely high success rate with the generally lower rehabilitation rate of traditional therapy. Also Bernard Wagner discusses the concept of “time out”.

results.title: Soft fruit
results.creator_credit: Christina Andreef, Helen Bowden, Film Finance Corporation Australia and Fox Searchlight Pictures
results.brief_description: An estranged and dysfunctional family are reunited when the matriarch of the clan is diagnosed with terminal cancer. Patsy is a stoic figure, keeping the family united, despite their fractured relationships. Patsy’s eldest daughter is a nurse, caring for her ailing mother; her other two daughters travel from Sydney and abroad with their respective children. Their brother, Bo, a biker with a history of drug abuse, is out of jail on special leave and has been disowned by his disapproving father. Vic, their father, is a disgruntled, violent figure who treats his children with disdain, whilst resenting their rallying around Patsy. The narrative is devoted to reconciliation between the disparate family members, in particular the relationship between father and son. In the spirit of black and bleak comedy, Christine Andreef’s debut feature is reminiscent of early Jane Campion work, in particular “Sweetie”; indeed “Soft fruit” has many of the hallmarks of that quirky Australian comedy. Contains scenes of great poignancy and humour, despite a certain unevenness in tenor. Cast includes Jeanie Drynan, Linal Haft, Russell Dykstra, Genevieve Lemon, Sacha Horler and Alicia Talbot.
